sentences.sentence: “That’s the woman, that’s the woman,” cried the fat man, pointing at Jadis. “Do your duty, Constable( 警察 ).
Hundreds and thousands of pounds’ worth she’s taken out of my shop.
Look at that rope of pearls( 珍珠 ) round her neck.
That’s mine. And she’s given me a black eye too, what’s more.”
“That she has, governor,” said one of the crowd. “And as lovely a black eye as I’d wish to see. Beautiful bit of work that must have been. Gor! Isn’t she strong then!”
“You ought to put a nice raw( 生的 ) beefsteak( 牛排 ) on it, Mister, that’s what it wants,” said a butcher’s( 肉铺 ) boy.
“Now then,” said the most important of the policemen, “what’s all this here?”
“I tell you she—” began the fat man, when someone else called out:
“Don’t let the old cove( 家伙 ) in the cab( 出租马车 ) get away. He put her up to it.”
The old gentleman, who was certainly Uncle Andrew, had just succeeded in standing up and was rubbing( 揉 ) his bruises( 瘀伤 ). “Now then,” said the policeman, turning to him, “What’s all this?”
“Womfle—pomfy—shomf,” came Uncle Andrew’s voice from inside the hat.
“None of that now,” said the policeman sternly( 严厉地 ). “You’ll find this is no laughing matter. Take that hat off, you see?”
This was more easily said than done.
But after Uncle Andrew had struggled in vain( 徒劳 ) with the hat for some time, two other policemen seized it by the brim( 帽檐 ) and forced it off.
“Thank you, thank you,” said Uncle Andrew in a faint( 虚弱的 ) voice. “Thank you. Dear me, I’m terribly shaken. If someone could give me a small glass of brandy( 白兰地 )—”
“Now you attend( 倾听 ) to me, if you please,” said the policeman, taking out a very large note book and a very small pencil. “Are you in charge of that there young woman?”
“Look out!” called several voices, and the policeman jumped a step backward( 向后 ) just in time.
The horse had aimed a kick at him which would probably have killed him.
Then the Witch( 女巫 ) wheeled the horse round so that she faced the crowd and its hind-legs( 后腿 ) were on the footpath.
She had a long, bright knife in her hand and had been busily cutting the horse free from the wreck( 残骸 ) of the hansom( 双轮有篷马车 ).
All this time Digory had been trying to get into a position from which he could touch the Witch( 女巫 ).
This wasn’t at all easy because, on the side nearest to him, there were too many people.
And in order to get round to the other side he had to pass between the horse’s hoofs( 马蹄 ) and the railings( 围栏 ) of the “area” that surrounded( 围绕 ) the house;
for the Ketterleys’ house had a basement( 地下室 ).
If you know anything about horses, and especially if you had seen what a state that horse was in at the moment,
you will realize that this was a ticklish( 棘手的 ) thing to do.
Digory knew lots about horses, but he set his teeth and got ready to make a dash( 冲 ) for it as soon as he saw a favorable moment.
A red-faced man in a bowler hat had now shouldered his way to the front of the crowd.
“Hi! P’leeceman,” he said, “that’s my horse what she’s sitting on, same as it’s my cab( 出租马车 ) what she’s made matchwood( 木材碎片 ) of.”
“One at a time, please, one at a time,” said the policeman.
“But there isn't any time,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I know that horse better than you do. It isn't an ordinary horse. His father was an officer's charger( 战马 ) in the cavalry( 骑兵部队 ), he was.
And if the young woman goes on exciting him, there’ll be murder done. Here, let me get at him.”
The policeman was only too glad to have a good reason for standing further away from the horse.
The Cabby( 马车夫 ) took a step nearer, looked up at Jadis, and said in a not unkindly voice:
“Now, Missie, let me get at his head, and you get off.
You’re a Lady, and you don’t want all these roughs going for you, do you?
You want to go home and have a nice cup of tea and a lay down quiet like; then you’ll feel ever so much better.”
At the same time he stretched( 伸出 ) out his hand toward the horse’s head with the words, “Steady( 镇定 ), Strawberry, old boy. Steady( 镇定 ) now.”
Then for the first time the Witch( 女巫 ) spoke.
“Dog!” came her cold, clear voice, ringing loud above all the other noises. “Dog, unhand( 放开 ) our royal charger. We are the Empress( 女王 ) Jadis.”
“Ho! Empress( 女王 ), are you? We’ll see about that,” said a voice.
Then another voice said, “Three cheers for the Empress( 女王 ) of Colney Hatch” and quite a number joined in.
A flush( 红晕 ) of color came into the Witch( 女巫 )’s face and she bowed ever so slightly.
But the cheers died away into roars( 哄笑 ) of laughter and she saw that they had only been making fun of( 嘲笑 ) her.
A change came over her expression and she changed the knife to her left hand.
Then, without warning, she did a thing that was dreadful( 可怕的 ) to see.
Lightly, easily, as if it were the most ordinary thing in the world, she stretched( 伸出 ) up her right arm and wrenched( 猛扭 ) off one of the cross-bars of the lamp-post.
If she had lost some magical powers in our world, she had not lost her strength; she could break an iron bar as if it were a stick of barley-sugar.
She tossed( 扔 ) her new weapon( 武器 ) up in the air, caught it again, brandished( 挥舞 ) it, and urged( 催促 ) the horse forward.
“Now’s my chance,” thought Digory. He darted( 飞奔 ) between the horse and the railings( 围栏 ) and began going forward.
If only the brute( 牲口 ) would stay still for a moment he might catch the Witch( 女巫 )’s heel.
As he rushed, he heard a sickening crash and a thud( 沉闷的声响 ).
The Witch( 女巫 ) had brought the bar down on the chief policeman’s helmet( 头盔 ): the man fell like a nine-pin.
“Quick, Digory. This must be stopped,” said a voice beside him. It was Polly, who had rushed down the moment she was allowed out of bed.
“You are a brick,” said Digory. “Hold on to me tight( 紧紧地 ). You’d have to manage the ring. Yellow, remember. And don’t put it on till I shout.”
There was a second crash and another policeman crumpled up( 瘫倒 ).
There came an angry roar( 吼叫声 ) from the crowd: “Pull her down. Get a few paving( 铺路的 )-stones. Call out the Military.”
But most of them were getting as far away as they could.
The Cabby( 马车夫 ), however, obviously the bravest as well as the kindest person present, was keeping close to the horse, dodging this way and that( 左闪右躲 ) to avoid the bar,
but still trying to catch Strawberry’s head.
The crowd booed( 发嘘声 ) and bellowed( 吼叫 ) again.
A stone whistled over Digory’s head.
Then came the voice of the Witch( 女巫 ), clear like a great bell, and sounding as if, for once, she were almost happy.
“Scum( 人渣 )! You shall pay dearly for( 付出沉重代价 ) this when I have conquered( 征服 ) your world. Not one stone of your city will be left.
I will make it as Charn, as Felinda, as Sorlois, as Bramandin.”
Digory at last caught her ankle( 脚踝 ).
She kicked back with her heel and hit him in the mouth.
In his pain he lost hold. His lip was cut and his mouth full of blood.
From somewhere very close by came the voice of Uncle Andrew in a sort of trembling( 颤抖的 ) scream.
“Madam( 女士 )—my dear young lady—for heaven’s sake( 看在上帝的份上 )—compose( 镇静下来 ) yourself.”
Digory made a second grab( 抓 ) at her heel, and was again shaken off.
More men were knocked down by the iron bar. He made a third grab( 抓 ): caught the heel: held on like grim death( 死不松手 ), shouting to Polly “Go!” then—Oh, thank goodness.
The angry, frightened faces had vanished( 消失 ). The angry, frightened voices were silenced.
All except Uncle Andrew’s. Close beside Digory in the darkness, it was wailing( 哀鸣 ) on “Oh, oh, is this delirium( 幻觉 )? Is it the end?
I can’t bear it. It’s not fair. I never meant to be a Magician.
It’s all a misunderstanding. It’s all my godmother( 教母 )’s fault;
I must protest( 抗议 ) against this. In my state of health too. A very old Dorsetshire family.”

article_info.previous: 此时Digory脑袋里想的都是如何把女巫带回魔法世界。然而，一位女士的拜访让Digory萌生出利用魔法拯救生病母亲的想法。而此时的女巫却把街上弄得天翻地覆，为了把女巫带回属于她的世界，为了拯救母亲，Digory毅然冲出了家门。

article_info.share_words: A flush of color came into the Witch’s face and she bowed ever so lightly. But the cheers died away into roars of laughter and she saw that they had only been making fun of her.

question.cn: 谁偷了胖子男人的项链？
question.en: Who stole the fat man’s pearl necklace?

analysis: 文中提到“That’s the woman, that’s the woman…pointing at Jadis. Do your duty, Constable. Hundreds and hundreds of pounds’ worth she’s taken out of my shop. Look at that rope of pearls round her neck. That’s mine.”由此可知是女巫Jadis偷了胖子的珍珠项链，因此选C。

question.en: Who took Uncle Andrew’s hat off?

analysis: 文中提到“But after Uncle Andrew had struggled in vain with the hat for some time, two policemen seized it by the brim and forced it off.”由此可知是两个警察把Uncle Andrew的帽子拿下来的，因此选A。

question.cn: 马车夫的马叫什么名字？
question.en: What was the name of the Cabby’s horse?

analysis: 文中提到“At the same time he stretched out his hand toward the horse’s head with words, Steady, Strawberry, old boy. Steady now.”由此可知女巫骑着的那匹马名叫“草莓”，因此选A。

question.cn: 当女巫开始说话时，她叫马车夫什么？
question.en: When the Witch began to speak, what did she call Cabby?

analysis: 文中提到“Then for the first time the Witch spoke. Dog! Came her cold, clear voice, ringing loud above all the other noises.”由此可知，女王叫马车夫“Dog”，因此选B。

question.cn: Digory抓住了女巫的哪个部位？
question.en: Which part of the Witch’s body did Digory catch?

analysis: 文中提到“Digory at last caught her ankle.”由此得知Digory最后抓住了女巫的脚踝，因此选C。
